segment.source: 4625(F) An account failed to log on.
segment.target: 4625(F) An account failed to log on.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4625(F) An account failed to log on.
segment.target: Describes security event 4625(F) An account failed to log on.

segment.source: 4625(F): An account failed to log on.
segment.target: 4625(F): An account failed to log on.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source:
Subcategories:
Audit Account Lockout and Audit Logon
segment.target:
Subcategories:
Audit Account Lockout and Audit Logon

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates if an account logon attempt failed when the account was already locked out.
segment.target: This event generates if an account logon attempt failed when the account was already locked out.

segment.source: It also generates for a logon attempt after which the account was locked out.
segment.target: It also generates for a logon attempt after which the account was locked out.

segment.source: It generates on the computer where logon attempt was made, for example, if logon attempt was made on user’s workstation, then event will be logged on this workstation.
segment.target: It generates on the computer where logon attempt was made, for example, if logon attempt was made on user’s workstation, then event will be logged on this workstation.

segment.source: This event generates on domain controllers, member servers, and workstations.
segment.target: This event generates on domain controllers, member servers, and workstations.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that reported information about logon failure.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that reported information about logon failure.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that reported information about logon failure.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that reported information about logon failure.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon Type Type = UInt32: the type of logon which was performed.
segment.target: Logon Type Type = UInt32: the type of logon which was performed.

segment.source: “Table 11.
segment.target: “Table 11.

segment.source: Windows Logon Types” contains the list of possible values for this field.
segment.target: Windows Logon Types” contains the list of possible values for this field.

segment.source: Logon Type
segment.target: Logon Type

segment.source: Logon Title
segment.target: Logon Title

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Interactive
segment.target: Interactive

segment.source: A user logged on to this computer.
segment.target: A user logged on to this computer.

segment.source: Network
segment.target: Network

segment.source: A user or computer logged on to this computer from the network.
segment.target: A user or computer logged on to this computer from the network.

segment.source: Batch
segment.target: Batch

segment.source: Batch logon type is used by batch servers, where processes may be executing on behalf of a user without their direct intervention.
segment.target: Batch logon type is used by batch servers, where processes may be executing on behalf of a user without their direct intervention.

segment.source: Service
segment.target: Service

segment.source: A service was started by the Service Control Manager.
segment.target: A service was started by the Service Control Manager.

segment.source: Unlock
segment.target: Unlock

segment.source: This workstation was unlocked.
segment.target: This workstation was unlocked.

segment.source: NetworkCleartext
segment.target: NetworkCleartext

segment.source: A user logged on to this computer from the network.
segment.target: A user logged on to this computer from the network.

segment.source: The user's password was passed to the authentication package in its unhashed form.
segment.target: The user's password was passed to the authentication package in its unhashed form.

segment.source: The built-in authentication packages all hash credentials before sending them across the network.
segment.target: The built-in authentication packages all hash credentials before sending them across the network.

segment.source: The credentials do not traverse the network in plaintext (also called cleartext).
segment.target: The credentials do not traverse the network in plaintext (also called cleartext).

segment.source: NewCredentials
segment.target: NewCredentials

segment.source: A caller cloned its current token and specified new credentials for outbound connections.
segment.target: A caller cloned its current token and specified new credentials for outbound connections.

segment.source: The new logon session has the same local identity, but uses different credentials for other network connections.
segment.target: The new logon session has the same local identity, but uses different credentials for other network connections.

segment.source: RemoteInteractive
segment.target: RemoteInteractive

segment.source: A user logged on to this computer remotely using Terminal Services or Remote Desktop.
segment.target: A user logged on to this computer remotely using Terminal Services or Remote Desktop.

segment.source: CachedInteractive
segment.target: CachedInteractive

segment.source: A user logged on to this computer with network credentials that were stored locally on the computer.
segment.target: A user logged on to this computer with network credentials that were stored locally on the computer.

segment.source: The domain controller was not contacted to verify the credentials.
segment.target: The domain controller was not contacted to verify the credentials.

segment.source: Table: Windows Logon Types
segment.target: Table: Windows Logon Types

segment.source: Account For Which Logon Failed:
segment.target: Account For Which Logon Failed:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of the account that was specified in the logon attempt.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of the account that was specified in the logon attempt.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that was specified in the logon attempt.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that was specified in the logon attempt.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Failure Information:
segment.target: Failure Information:

segment.source: Failure Reason Type = UnicodeString: textual explanation of Status field value.
segment.target: Failure Reason Type = UnicodeString: textual explanation of Status field value.

segment.source: For this event it typically has “Account locked out” value.
segment.target: For this event it typically has “Account locked out” value.

segment.source: Status Type = HexInt32: the reason why logon failed.
segment.target: Status Type = HexInt32: the reason why logon failed.

segment.source: For this event it typically has “0xC0000234” value.
segment.target: For this event it typically has “0xC0000234” value.

segment.source: The most common status codes are listed in “Table 12.
segment.target: The most common status codes are listed in “Table 12.

segment.source: Windows logon status codes.”
segment.target: Windows logon status codes.”

segment.source: StatusSub-Status Code
segment.target: StatusSub-Status Code

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: There are currently no logon servers available to service the logon request.
segment.target: There are currently no logon servers available to service the logon request.

segment.source: User logon with misspelled or bad user account
segment.target: User logon with misspelled or bad user account

segment.source: User logon with misspelled or bad password
segment.target: User logon with misspelled or bad password

segment.source: This is either due to a bad username or authentication information
segment.target: This is either due to a bad username or authentication information

segment.source: Unknown user name or bad password.
segment.target: Unknown user name or bad password.

segment.source: User logon outside authorized hours
segment.target: User logon outside authorized hours

segment.source: User logon from unauthorized workstation
segment.target: User logon from unauthorized workstation

segment.source: User logon with expired password
segment.target: User logon with expired password

segment.source: User logon to account disabled by administrator
segment.target: User logon to account disabled by administrator

segment.source: 0XC00000DC
segment.target: 0XC00000DC

segment.source: Indicates the Sam Server was in the wrong state to perform the desired operation.
segment.target: Indicates the Sam Server was in the wrong state to perform the desired operation.

segment.source: Clocks between DC and other computer too far out of sync
segment.target: Clocks between DC and other computer too far out of sync

segment.source: The user has not been granted the requested logon type (aka logon right) at this machine
segment.target: The user has not been granted the requested logon type (aka logon right) at this machine

segment.source: The logon request failed because the trust relationship between the primary domain and the trusted domain failed.
segment.target: The logon request failed because the trust relationship between the primary domain and the trusted domain failed.

segment.source: An attempt was made to logon, but the Netlogon service was not started.
segment.target: An attempt was made to logon, but the Netlogon service was not started.

segment.source: User logon with expired account
segment.target: User logon with expired account

segment.source: User is required to change password at next logon
segment.target: User is required to change password at next logon

segment.source: Evidently a bug in Windows and not a risk
segment.target: Evidently a bug in Windows and not a risk

segment.source: User logon with account locked
segment.target: User logon with account locked

segment.source: 0XC00002EE
segment.target: 0XC00002EE

segment.source: Failure Reason: An Error occurred during Logon
segment.target: Failure Reason: An Error occurred during Logon

segment.source: Logon Failure: The machine you are logging onto is protected by an authentication firewall.
segment.target: Logon Failure: The machine you are logging onto is protected by an authentication firewall.

segment.source: The specified account is not allowed to authenticate to the machine.
segment.target: The specified account is not allowed to authenticate to the machine.

segment.source: Status OK.
segment.target: Status OK.

segment.source: Table: Windows logon status codes.
segment.target: Table: Windows logon status codes.

segment.source: Note To see the meaning of other statussub-status codes you may also check for status code in the Window header file ntstatus.h in Windows SDK.
segment.target: Note To see the meaning of other statussub-status codes you may also check for status code in the Window header file ntstatus.h in Windows SDK.

segment.source: More information: https://dev.windows.com/en-us/downloads
segment.target: More information: https://dev.windows.com/en-us/downloads

segment.source: Sub Status Type = HexInt32: additional information about logon failure.
segment.target: Sub Status Type = HexInt32: additional information about logon failure.

segment.source: The most common sub-status codes listed in the “Table 12.
segment.target: The most common sub-status codes listed in the “Table 12.

segment.source: Windows logon status codes.”.
segment.target: Windows logon status codes.”.

segment.source: Process Information:
segment.target: Process Information:

segment.source: Caller Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process that attempted the logon.
segment.target: Caller Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process that attempted the logon.

segment.source: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
segment.target: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

segment.source: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):
segment.target: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.
segment.target: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.

segment.source: Caller Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.
segment.target: Caller Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.

segment.source: Network Information:
segment.target: Network Information:

segment.source: Workstation Name Type = UnicodeString: machine name from which logon attempt was performed.
segment.target: Workstation Name Type = UnicodeString: machine name from which logon attempt was performed.

segment.source: Source Network Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of machine from which logon attempt was performed.
segment.target: Source Network Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of machine from which logon attempt was performed.

segment.source: IPv6 address or ::ffff:IPv4 address of a client.
segment.target: IPv6 address or ::ffff:IPv4 address of a client.

segment.source: ::1 or 127.0.0.1 means localhost.
segment.target: ::1 or 127.0.0.1 means localhost.

segment.source: Source Port Type = UnicodeString: source port which was used for logon attempt from remote machine.
segment.target: Source Port Type = UnicodeString: source port which was used for logon attempt from remote machine.

segment.source: 0 for interactive logons.
segment.target: 0 for interactive logons.

segment.source: Detailed Authentication Information:
segment.target: Detailed Authentication Information:

segment.source: Logon Process Type = UnicodeString: the name of the trusted logon process that was used for the logon attempt.
segment.target: Logon Process Type = UnicodeString: the name of the trusted logon process that was used for the logon attempt.

segment.source: See event “4611: A trusted logon process has been registered with the Local Security Authority” description for more information.
segment.target: See event “4611: A trusted logon process has been registered with the Local Security Authority” description for more information.

segment.source: Authentication Package Type = UnicodeString: The name of the authentication package which was used for the logon authentication process.
segment.target: Authentication Package Type = UnicodeString: The name of the authentication package which was used for the logon authentication process.

segment.source: Default packages loaded on LSA startup are located in “HKLMSYSTEMCurrentControlSetControlLsaOSConfig” registry key.
segment.target: Default packages loaded on LSA startup are located in “HKLMSYSTEMCurrentControlSetControlLsaOSConfig” registry key.

segment.source: Other packages can be loaded at runtime.
segment.target: Other packages can be loaded at runtime.

segment.source: When a new package is loaded a “4610: An authentication package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority” (typically for NTLM) or “4622: A security package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority” (typically for Kerberos) event is logged to indicate that a new package has been loaded along with the package name.
segment.target: When a new package is loaded a “4610: An authentication package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority” (typically for NTLM) or “4622: A security package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority” (typically for Kerberos) event is logged to indicate that a new package has been loaded along with the package name.

segment.source: The most common authentication packages are:
segment.target: The most common authentication packages are:

segment.source: NTLM – NTLM-family Authentication
segment.target: NTLM – NTLM-family Authentication

segment.source: Kerberos – Kerberos authentication.
segment.target: Kerberos – Kerberos authentication.

segment.source: Negotiate – the Negotiate security package selects between Kerberos and NTLM protocols.
segment.target: Negotiate – the Negotiate security package selects between Kerberos and NTLM protocols.

segment.source: Negotiate selects Kerberos unless it cannot be used by one of the systems involved in the authentication or the calling application did not provide sufficient information to use Kerberos.
segment.target: Negotiate selects Kerberos unless it cannot be used by one of the systems involved in the authentication or the calling application did not provide sufficient information to use Kerberos.

segment.source: Transited Services Type = UnicodeStringKerberos-only: the list of transmitted services.
segment.target: Transited Services Type = UnicodeStringKerberos-only: the list of transmitted services.

segment.source: Transmitted services are populated if the logon was a result of a S4U (Service For User) logon process.
segment.target: Transmitted services are populated if the logon was a result of a S4U (Service For User) logon process.

segment.source: S4U is a Microsoft extension to the Kerberos Protocol to allow an application service to obtain a Kerberos service ticket on behalf of a user – most commonly done by a front-end website to access an internal resource on behalf of a user.
segment.target: S4U is a Microsoft extension to the Kerberos Protocol to allow an application service to obtain a Kerberos service ticket on behalf of a user – most commonly done by a front-end website to access an internal resource on behalf of a user.

segment.source: For more information about S4U, see https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc246072.aspx
segment.target: For more information about S4U, see https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc246072.aspx

segment.source: Package Name (NTLM only) Type = UnicodeString: The name of the LAN Manager sub-package (NTLM-family protocol name) that was used during the logon attempt.
segment.target: Package Name (NTLM only) Type = UnicodeString: The name of the LAN Manager sub-package (NTLM-family protocol name) that was used during the logon attempt.

segment.source: Possible values are:
segment.target: Possible values are:

segment.source: “NTLM V1”
segment.target: “NTLM V1”

segment.source: “NTLM V2”
segment.target: “NTLM V2”

segment.source: “LM”
segment.target: “LM”

segment.source: Only populated if “Authentication Package” = “NTLM”.
segment.target: Only populated if “Authentication Package” = “NTLM”.

segment.source: Key Length Type = UInt32: the length of NTLM Session Security key.
segment.target: Key Length Type = UInt32: the length of NTLM Session Security key.

segment.source: Typically it has 128 bit or 56 bit length.
segment.target: Typically it has 128 bit or 56 bit length.

segment.source: This parameter is always 0 if “Authentication Package” = “Kerberos”, because it is not applicable for Kerberos protocol.
segment.target: This parameter is always 0 if “Authentication Package” = “Kerberos”, because it is not applicable for Kerberos protocol.

segment.source: This field will also have “0” value if Kerberos was negotiated using Negotiate authentication package.
segment.target: This field will also have “0” value if Kerberos was negotiated using Negotiate authentication package.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4625(F): An account failed to log on.
segment.target: For 4625(F): An account failed to log on.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.

segment.source: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).
segment.target: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”

segment.source: If SubjectAccount Name is a name of service account or user account, it may be useful to investigate whether that account is allowed (or expected) to request logon for Account For Which Logon FailedSecurity ID.
segment.target: If SubjectAccount Name is a name of service account or user account, it may be useful to investigate whether that account is allowed (or expected) to request logon for Account For Which Logon FailedSecurity ID.

segment.source: To monitor for a mismatch between the logon type and the account that uses it (for example, if Logon Type 4-Batch or 5-Service is used by a member of a domain administrative group), monitor Logon Type in this event.
segment.target: To monitor for a mismatch between the logon type and the account that uses it (for example, if Logon Type 4-Batch or 5-Service is used by a member of a domain administrative group), monitor Logon Type in this event.

segment.source: If you have a high-value domain or local account for which you need to monitor every lockout, monitor all 4625 events with the “SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the account.
segment.target: If you have a high-value domain or local account for which you need to monitor every lockout, monitor all 4625 events with the “SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring all 4625 events for local accounts, because these accounts typically should not be locked out.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring all 4625 events for local accounts, because these accounts typically should not be locked out.

segment.source: This is especially relevant for critical servers, administrative workstations, and other high value assets.
segment.target: This is especially relevant for critical servers, administrative workstations, and other high value assets.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring all 4625 events for service accounts, because these accounts should not be locked out or prevented from functioning.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring all 4625 events for service accounts, because these accounts should not be locked out or prevented from functioning.

segment.source: This is especially relevant for critical servers, administrative workstations, and other high value assets.
segment.target: This is especially relevant for critical servers, administrative workstations, and other high value assets.

segment.source: If your organization restricts logons in the following ways, you can use this event to monitor accordingly:
segment.target: If your organization restricts logons in the following ways, you can use this event to monitor accordingly:

segment.source: If the “Account For Which Logon Failed Security ID” should never be used to log on from the specific Network InformationWorkstation Name.
segment.target: If the “Account For Which Logon Failed Security ID” should never be used to log on from the specific Network InformationWorkstation Name.

segment.source: If a specific account, such as a service account, should only be used from your internal IP address list (or some other list of IP addresses).
segment.target: If a specific account, such as a service account, should only be used from your internal IP address list (or some other list of IP addresses).

segment.source: In this case, you can monitor for Network InformationSource Network Address and compare the network address with your list of IP addresses.
segment.target: In this case, you can monitor for Network InformationSource Network Address and compare the network address with your list of IP addresses.

segment.source: If a particular version of NTLM is always used in your organization.
segment.target: If a particular version of NTLM is always used in your organization.

segment.source: In this case, you can use this event to monitor Package Name (NTLM only), for example, to find events where Package Name (NTLM only) does not equal NTLM V2.
segment.target: In this case, you can use this event to monitor Package Name (NTLM only), for example, to find events where Package Name (NTLM only) does not equal NTLM V2.

segment.source: If NTLM is not used in your organization, or should not be used by a specific account (New LogonSecurity ID).
segment.target: If NTLM is not used in your organization, or should not be used by a specific account (New LogonSecurity ID).

segment.source: In this case, monitor for all events where Authentication Package is NTLM.
segment.target: In this case, monitor for all events where Authentication Package is NTLM.

segment.source: If the Authentication Package is NTLM.
segment.target: If the Authentication Package is NTLM.

segment.source: In this case, monitor for Key Length not equal to 128, because all Windows operating systems starting with Windows 2000 support 128-bit Key Length.
segment.target: In this case, monitor for Key Length not equal to 128, because all Windows operating systems starting with Windows 2000 support 128-bit Key Length.

segment.source: If Logon Process is not from a trusted logon processes list.
segment.target: If Logon Process is not from a trusted logon processes list.

segment.source: Monitor for all events with the fields and values in the following table:
segment.target: Monitor for all events with the fields and values in the following table:

segment.source: Field
segment.target: Field

segment.source: Value to monitor for
segment.target: Value to monitor for

segment.source: Failure InformationStatus or
segment.target: Failure InformationStatus or

segment.source: Failure InformationSub Status
segment.target: Failure InformationSub Status

segment.source: 0XC000005E – “There are currently no logon servers available to service the logon request.”
segment.target: 0XC000005E – “There are currently no logon servers available to service the logon request.”

segment.source: This is typically not a security issue but it can be an infrastructure or availability issue.
segment.target: This is typically not a security issue but it can be an infrastructure or availability issue.

segment.source: Failure InformationStatus or
segment.target: Failure InformationStatus or

segment.source: Failure InformationSub Status
segment.target: Failure InformationSub Status

segment.source: 0xC0000064 – “User logon with misspelled or bad user account”.
segment.target: 0xC0000064 – “User logon with misspelled or bad user account”.

segment.source: Especially if you get a number of these in a row, it can be a sign of user enumeration attack.
segment.target: Especially if you get a number of these in a row, it can be a sign of user enumeration attack.

segment.source: Failure InformationStatus or
segment.target: Failure InformationStatus or

segment.source: Failure InformationSub Status
segment.target: Failure InformationSub Status

segment.source: 0xC000006A – “User logon with misspelled or bad password” for critical accounts or service accounts.
segment.target: 0xC000006A – “User logon with misspelled or bad password” for critical accounts or service accounts.

segment.source: Especially watch for a number of such events in a row.
segment.target: Especially watch for a number of such events in a row.

segment.target: Failure InformationStatus or

segment.target: Failure InformationSub Status

segment.source: Especially watch for a number of such events in a row.
segment.target: Especially watch for a number of such events in a row.

segment.target: 0XC0000192 – “An attempt was made to logon, but the Netlogon service was not started”.

segment.source: This is typically not a security issue but it can be an infrastructure or availability issue.

segment.source: 0XC0000413 – “Logon Failure: The machine you are logging onto is protected by an authentication firewall.
segment.target: 0XC0000413 – “Logon Failure: The machine you are logging onto is protected by an authentication firewall.

segment.source: The specified account is not allowed to authenticate to the machine”.
segment.target: The specified account is not allowed to authenticate to the machine”.
